title: Innovation: Finding Europe’s path to competitiveness
text:
Innovation is a crucial component of the European Commission’s agenda. Why? Because it lies at the intersection of its employment, competitiveness and industrial performance. It impacts citizens as both workers and consumers.

But Europe spends 0.8% of GDP less than the US and 1.5% less than Japan every year on research and development. It also has a fragmented market made up of 28 member states. The question facing the new European policymakers is: what innovation policies should the EU pursue to make sure it remains competitive and able to build challengers to countries like the US, Japan and South Korea?

Questions to be addressed include:

• What can the EU and member states do to create a more favourable environment to R&D and innovation?

• Who invests in R&D and how? How are the EU and member states sharing this responsibility? And how do public and private investment interact?

• The U.S. and China fund a lot of research via military and space programs among others. How can the EU and its member states fund innovation to compete? Is there a different “European way” to innovation?

• Should the EU’s new industrial policy put more money in research, education, innovation?

• What is the role of intellectual property law and standards in fostering research and innovation? Is Europe using it in a way that incentivizes innovation?

This POLITICO event is gathering policymakers, analyst and business leaders to unfold the intricacies of the EU’s innovation policy mix and how it affects the Continent’s competitiveness on the world stage.
